237 Oakwood Blvd.
To Dr. Martezuma: 
My dear Doctor:
Could you have heard 
the kindly words of 
praise spoken of you
and your touching
remarks of this after-
noon I am sure you 
would feel that you 
had done a good
work and given
b05e00988542f32c2bee317d82debf5c.jpg

food for conjecture
as well as great pleasure
to your hearers.
May our Father 
aid you in the work
you have undertaken
and my you (unlike
La Salle) live to see the fruits of your
labor. If in my 
feeble way I can at
any time serve you
please command
e6325d22e87f9a0a1b7ab2e1d92a1194.jpg

me. Thanking you
over an over again
I am sincerely and
gratefully yours,
Janet M. Dickson
(Mrs. N. J.)
June Second 1904

Dear Friend, 
I reached my destination yesterday about 11 O clock. The train was fully two or three hours late on account of the wreck we had near Dunkirk a distance of eighty miles from Buffalo. On the way just before we reached the place named? alone, one of the driving wheel's come off, and we had gone a quarter of a mile before the train could be stopped. The air brakes did not work at all to any advantage. no? one was hurt but the engineer. She had
21af882ff1fdcdd385e3adec0670b221.jpg

his foot all battered up. Still he was ready to he at his foot again when a new engine came to assist. We stopped over a high bridge and if the connecting rods had caught the tiles we might have tipped over in the stream! The engineer's? cabin just went into fragments with the steam pump. I have a unclear as a relic. I went by the headquarters to make an application for guard unclear but as I have troubled with my eyes and Rheumatism, I stand no chance of getting in. I will try for gate keeper. The city is just crowded with people. They are plenty here looking for employment now. The buildings on the fair grounds are not done with

It will take fully than
month and half before
it looks anything like
The Parr American Apposition
It will not be worth look-
ing at till about the middle
of June or first part of 
July. I will let you know
soon how I am situated
Remember me to Mrs. Brainred
and Miss Getzinges
Excuse the condition of 
my letter.
Faithfully yours
John Dilton

March 11th, 1903.
Dear Dr. Montezuma;-
Indeed I am 
not surprised that you do not
remember me. Skav?, could one be
expected to remember a paleface
when there are so many fine Indian
faces to remember.
I did walk with 
Miss Sophia American Skorse? the day
you left, and my friend Miss Atsye
(the trained muse) and I were going 
to Philadelphia in the same train

with you and Dr. Rosa Minoka but we missed
the train. Now if you do not remember me,
perhaps I can recall something that will bring
you back to the trail.
One evening at Carlisle I lost 
my friends in the crowd while going to the 
gymnasium and I met you. You started
right off and found them for me in a very 
few minutes. Then you guided me to them
and I was very thankful to my Indian
guide.
You did not promise me anything
for the pictures, but if you ever have a picture
of yourself to spare would like to have it
Very sincerely
(Miss) Marian S. Duffie
1627 Mt. Vermon Street
Philadelphia, Penn
b1c0c40ac26e7712cafc1f9f1a291e15.jpg

February 19th, 1903
Dr. Carlos Montezuma,
Chicago, Ill.
Dear Doctor Montezuma;-
In this 
same mail I send you the pictures
I promised to give you while we were
at Carlisle. I think they are very fine
photographs of both men, and I hope
you will like them. 
Very sincerely yours
Marian S. Duffie
1627 Mount Vernon Street
Philadelphia.

Southampton Ont. Dec. 24, 1907
Carlos Montezuma M.D.
My dear friend:- I regret exceedingly that
your estimable letter comes little too late, when
all the festival entertainments have already been an-
nounced and advertized: it is regretted that those
entertainments cannot be altered to suck our own:
You will aware that there is so much competition
between Churches which respectively lead to other
by furnishing most excellent programs. Had you
written earlier, it was my purpose, and my friends agreing
with me, that in the other Churches might have clubbed
with us to secure your excellent services. but so short
a time to give notices for your lectures, may confuse other
public entertainments already posted. Then if we were to spring
on the people at New Year's feast for contributions might leave
us on the humiliation to find ourselves minus of the required 
sum: however, if you could take what we could collect that 
day we would do the best: regretting very much for our failure 
to get your amount us. We greet you deeply from our hearts. Merry
Christmas and Happy New Year. let me hear from you by return mail
We are all well, all would be most happy to see you.
Your true friend W.A. Elias
Southampton
Ontario

Traverse City, Mich. Apr 16 1908
Dr Carlos Montezuma
Chicago, Ill.
Dear Sir and Brother.- We are planning for our
Indian Campmeeting at Northport, Mich to be held
Aug 6th to 16th. I understand that you have been
there once and know where it is.
Would it be possible for you to come again and 
speak on Sunday either the 9th or the 16th of Aug. and 
also on Saturday or Monday?
The Indians are trying to build a periannual
tabernacle to hold their services in, and it looks
now as if they may succeed, ut it will be quite an 
effort for them and they would not feel as it they
could afford to pay mch above expenses for their
speakers this year.
If you could come we would appreciate it very
much, though we know it is asking much of you for you must be a very busy man.
An early reply will oblige
Yours very sincerely
A. R. Ferguson
P.S. Could you give me Dr. Eeasluian's? address?
A.R.F.

Traverse City, Mich., July 22 1908
Carlos Montezuma
Chicago, Ill.
Dear Sir and Brother.- Under another cover
I am sending you a copy of the Program
for the Northport-Indian Camp meeting.
You will see that we are depending upon
you for Sunday Aug 16. I trust no preventing
providence may hinder you from being there
Yours Sincerely, 
A.R. Ferguson

Milwaukee Sept 10th 07
Dear friend Dr. Montezuma
I suppose you will be
surprised to hear from
me I have been ill about
10 months it was hard 
work for me to get here
in Milwaukee we would
like to have seen you
but couldn't make it
so we are back to dear
[[of [crossed out]] old Milwaukee I had
a pretty hard time of it
Dr. I wish you would
[[unclear[crossed out]] tell me what to 
take for gas in the stomach
we were reading a piece
about you in the Sunday
Magazine which was
b4a417ecb26eb201803f1c63f553bd3f.jpg

very interesting hoping
to hear from you soon
I am as every your
friend Mrs Fred Fish
451 Jefferson St
Milwaukee
Wis.

125 Prospect St
Cambridgeport, Mass.
3 March, 1909.
Dr. Carlos Montezuma,
Dear Sir,
I have sent to Prof. A.
Lawrence Lowell, trustee of the Lowell
Institute course of free lecturns, the
list of your lecture subjects also
your address + I hope you will
hear from him asking you to speak
next [?] in Boston.
I am very anxious to have the 
North American Indian better known
+ understood. I feel [?] too that 
it would be a subject which would 
interest the public.
Yours sincerely, 
Ammir Fuller

Connellsville Pa 2/4.09

Dear Dr

Muskegon Mich
Mar. 23-
My Dear Doctor
I am writting to let you know that 
I am now the Father 
of an 8 pound girl.
She was born monday-
morning about 9.20-
hard time and we had
to have two doctors
and a nurse which 
was very expensive and 
I would like to know
if you can let me have
$50.00 until I can get on
1ea23195c95fa7c45883f35715aa9fbe.jpg

my feet as my
money is all tied
up for the time
am going to dipose of
some property that I 
have here and as soon 
as I do I can repay you.
I do not think I will 
need it more than a 
month but for the present
I am up against it.
I also want to take
a couse in a school
for the Government
Civil Service Examinations
to be held in May. I wish
to get into the Government 
service.
78ff08c3d3da83d0f2aa2d5bfc314549.jpg

as nothing else seems
to be open at present.
We saw your name
in the Grand Rapids
paper the other day saying 
that you were to speak
there did you have a 
good audience? I would 
like to have been able 
to be there. Hoping you are well and that I will
hear from you soon
I remain
Yours resp.
Carlos Gentile
Address [arrow] Chas. H. Sutton
17 E. Clay Ave
Muskegon

Urbana, Ill.
Dec. 28. '97
Dr. Montezuma,
Dear Sir;
I hope
I am not going to dis-
commode you by ask-
ing this favor of you, 
but I have a subject be-
fore a club which wor-
ries me a great deal.
My subject is "The Indian
of Today". I do not know
where to go to get mate-
rial for the subject,
so I concluded to write
to you and ask for any information

time to give me.
I shall feel very grate-
ful to you [[your] crossed out] for
your kindness.
Respectfully,
Aureka B. Kiler,
104 California St.
Urbana,
Ill.

1110 Leland Cove
July 14, '09
My dear D. Montezuma--
Please accept my warmest thanks for your generous gift. In all we received twenty five dollars and that gave us a good start now on a china set. 
It would please me very much if you would come unclear and eat off of those dishes - of course
1390c2475caab8c3b606ff0b9ca86c92.jpg

I know you are not fond of eating, so you could put up with my cooking for one meal
I was so disappointed not to see you the evening of June 16th Jane and Clara were both there, but I explained your absence. 
Thanking you again - I am 
Yours Sincerely,
Lizzie Mae Kuerten
